quotes.topic_title: First-principles thinking and innovation at Dropbox
quotes.text: My aha moment of the value of first principles thinking was when I was at Dropbox.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: Highlights first-principles thinking as a key mental model that shaped how Dropbox approached problems and innovation.

quotes.topic_title: First-principles thinking and innovation at Dropbox
quotes.text: We would hire a ton of really smart people that had never done sales and had them do sales.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: A concrete, counterintuitive hiring and role-design tactic: put high-aptitude novices into sales to unlock fresh approaches.

quotes.topic_title: First-principles thinking and innovation at Dropbox
quotes.text: There are a lot of disadvantages to that, but I do think it led to a ton of innovation.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: Frames the tradeoff explicitly—accepting short-term downsides can produce outsized innovation benefits.

quotes.topic_title: First-principles thinking and innovation at Dropbox
quotes.text: That's how we got our very innovative go-to market motions because a lot of those people then moved into different functions at the company.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: Shows a repeatable mechanism: rotate sales-exposed talent into other functions to transfer customer context and improve GTM innovation.

quotes.topic_title: First-principles thinking and innovation at Dropbox
quotes.text: If you take people that are just super smart, they've never done it before, one advantage of that is they can innovate because I think they come in with, I don't know anything. Let me just figure this out.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: Captures a practical innovation heuristic: leverage beginner’s mind to avoid inherited assumptions and discover new solutions.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Melissa shares advice for becoming a leader that people will follow from company to company, how to best develop your people to become the best versions of themselves.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights two practitioner-relevant leadership themes: building portable followership and systematically developing talent.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We also get into how to interview product managers and she shares her actual interview process, plus who your first growth hire should probably be, the most common mistakes people make when they first start to invest in growth and a real talk story of what Dropbox did right and what they did wrong in their shift to B2B.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Previews concrete, repeatable methods (PM interviewing process, first growth hire) and a specific case study (Dropbox’s B2B shift).

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: So if you're looking for help with go-to market plans, growth strategy, building your growth team, aligning your sales, marketing and growth efforts, she's about to become available, so definitely reach out.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Calls out key operational levers teams can act on immediately: GTM planning, growth strategy, team design, and cross-functional alignment.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: What I love about AssemblyAI is you can use their simple API to access the latest AI breakthroughs from top tier research labs, product team that startups and enterprises are using AssemblyAI to automatically transcribe and summarize phone calls and virtual meetings, detect topics in podcasts, pinpoint when sensitive content is spoken and lots more.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Highlights concrete, high-leverage audio AI use cases practitioners can implement quickly via an API (transcription, summarization, topic detection, sensitive-content detection).

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: All of AssemblyAI's models, which are accessed through their API are production ready.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Emphasizes deployability—useful for teams evaluating whether an AI vendor is ready for real-world production workloads.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Mixpanel gives you quick answers about your users from awareness to acquisition through retention, and by capturing website activity, ad data, and multi-touch attribution right in Mixpanel, you can improve every aspect of the full user funnel.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Provides a practical methodology for funnel optimization by unifying behavioral, marketing, and attribution data in one analytics system.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Powered by first party behavioral data instead of third party cookies, Mixpanel's built to be more powerful and easier to use than Google Analytics.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: A counterpoint to cookie-dependent analytics approaches, pointing practitioners toward first-party behavioral data as the foundation.

quotes.topic_title: Melissa’s transition back to full-time advising
quotes.text: Over the last couple years I've been at Webflow building out the growth team there.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: Highlights hands-on experience scaling a growth function inside a company, signaling practical operator context behind her advising.

quotes.topic_title: Melissa’s transition back to full-time advising
quotes.text: I'm actually transitioning right now and I'm out right now and I'm going to go back into advising, which is something I was doing a lot of before Webflow working, having been fortunate enough to work with great companies like Canva, Grammarly, Miro, et cetera.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: Establishes her return to advising and grounds it in specific examples of companies she’s supported.

quotes.topic_title: Melissa’s transition back to full-time advising
quotes.text: And so that's one of my biggest passions is working with earlier stage companies once they found product market fit and helping them scale growth.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: Defines a clear focus area—post-PMF growth scaling—that practitioners can map to when to seek help and what stage-specific problems to prioritize.

quotes.topic_title: Advising focus areas and how to contact her
quotes.text: So a lot of companies initially as they're thinking about their go-to market strategy, should they be product led? Should they lean more into sales motion? What should the pricing and packaging look like?
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: A practical set of core GTM decision questions teams can use to structure early-stage strategy discussions.

quotes.topic_title: Advising focus areas and how to contact her
quotes.text: I've worked with earlier stage companies and then also post product market fit as companies are building out growth and they want to make sure to optimize the funnel across activation, monetization, engagement retention.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: Highlights a full-funnel optimization model (activation → monetization → engagement/retention) for post-PMF growth work.

quotes.topic_title: Advising focus areas and how to contact her
quotes.text: I've also advised and helped growth teams, so kind of across stages focus on growth and go-to market.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: Emphasizes that growth and GTM are cross-stage capabilities, not just a late-stage function.

quotes.topic_title: Advising focus areas and how to contact her
quotes.text: Definitely LinkedIn is a good place. I check my LinkedIn, so feel free to reach out there.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: Clear, actionable guidance on the most reliable channel to contact her for help.

quotes.topic_title: Dropbox growth: what worked and what didn’t
quotes.text: They looked for first principles thinkers, so not necessarily your experience, but how do you approach problems, how do you know the right questions to ask? And then create your own framework around that.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: A concrete hiring rubric that prioritizes problem-solving approach over resume credentials.

quotes.topic_title: Dropbox growth: what worked and what didn’t
quotes.text: Also, broadly speaking, the company just infused the topic of hiring and recruiting into the culture.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: Highlights a scalable operating principle: make recruiting a shared, explicit company responsibility.

quotes.topic_title: Dropbox growth: what worked and what didn’t
quotes.text: but what we found is the devil, I like to say the devils and the details and the devils and how you execute.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: A memorable reminder that iteration quality and execution details often determine whether “growth doesn’t work” is actually true.

quotes.topic_title: Dropbox growth: what worked and what didn’t
quotes.text: I think the blessing and the curse of early success is that you can get pulled in so many different directions
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: A counterintuitive warning that early traction can create strategic diffusion unless focus is deliberately managed.

quotes.topic_title: Dropbox growth: what worked and what didn’t
quotes.text: I think the best way to execute is just to have that be front and center from the start. What is our go-to market strategy? How are we thinking about monetization and having that infused into how you think about product development?
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: A clear methodology for embedding GTM and monetization into product development early rather than layering “growth” on later.

quotes.topic_title: When to add sales to a product-led motion
quotes.text: And so a trend I've seen is starting product-led first and the signal is that is a good motion for you is if the product is really intuitive to onboard onto. There's a low learning curve so you don't need a human to onboard the user. Also, if there's a viral component to it, that is really what can take.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: A practical decision framework for when PLG is the right initial go-to-market motion (intuitive onboarding + virality).

quotes.topic_title: When to add sales to a product-led motion
quotes.text: And initially I think when you have scale, you're getting a lot of signal on what is resonating with the user.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: Highlights how PLG at scale becomes a learning engine that informs what to double down on before adding sales.

quotes.topic_title: When to add sales to a product-led motion
quotes.text: This happened at Dropbox being like, "I need you to build SSO for me. I need you to build all these enterprise grade features. It's not secure enough." And so you are also collecting the list of things you need to build on the enterprise side.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: Concrete example of self-serve demand pulling a product into enterprise requirements (SSO/security) and shaping the roadmap.

quotes.topic_title: When to add sales to a product-led motion
quotes.text: And so I think it's typically looking like you might start product-led, then go enterprise.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: A memorable sequencing model for evolving from PLG to enterprise sales once enterprise needs emerge.

quotes.topic_title: When to add sales to a product-led motion
quotes.text: And then the other direction I've seen is some companies initially are just more conducive to an enterprise in sales motion. Potentially, you need to build custom things for these users. It's also not a bottom-up motion. Maybe the way you sell the product starts with the legal team or the finance team or some important stakeholder, but then a lot of companies now are trying to make that shift to make the product more accessible and go product led.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: Explains the opposite path—starting sales-led due to stakeholder-driven buying/custom needs, then simplifying toward PLG.

quotes.topic_title: Leading so people follow you across companies
quotes.text: I've worked with a few folks from my early Dropbox team that I've known for 10 years now, like a couple of times. In some case, three times.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: A concrete example of repeat followership over a decade, underscoring the strength of long-term trust and leadership impact.

quotes.topic_title: Leading so people follow you across companies
quotes.text: I have a very people focused approach to how I lead and manage.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: A clear leadership philosophy that frames the rest of her approach as intentionally people-first.

quotes.topic_title: Leading so people follow you across companies
quotes.text: I really think the core of it is deeply caring about people, building that trust, investing in their career development, helping them figure out where they want to go in their career.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: A practical, repeatable set of behaviors that leaders can apply to earn loyalty and drive retention.

quotes.topic_title: Leading so people follow you across companies
quotes.text: I think it just comes down to deeply caring and everything, all your actions follow through from there.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: A memorable mental model: start with genuine care as the root cause, and let tactics and decisions flow from it.

quotes.topic_title: Balancing care with high performance expectations
quotes.text: I don't think that they're mutually exclusive of each other because I think the other thing that I really emphasize on my team is being very results oriented.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: Reframes the common leadership tradeoff by asserting care and performance expectations can coexist.

quotes.topic_title: Balancing care with high performance expectations
quotes.text: And so I actually think this is why a lot of folks on my team, something that they actually appreciate is knowing what success looks like and knowing how they'll be measured.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: Highlights that clear measurement and defined success criteria can be experienced as supportive, not harsh.

quotes.topic_title: Balancing care with high performance expectations
quotes.text: And I actually create a very results-oriented culture on the team where it's clear what our goals are, we break it down into the individual levers, it's clear how success is measured for each individual.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: Provides a practical methodology for operationalizing high performance through goal clarity, levers, and individual measurement.

quotes.topic_title: Balancing care with high performance expectations
quotes.text: And then my role as a leader is also supporting their career growth, helping them meet those goals and giving them feedback along the way.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: Defines a concrete leader operating model: pair measurable goals with coaching, growth support, and ongoing feedback.

quotes.topic_title: Direct feedback as an act of care
quotes.text: I think sometimes as a manager it can maybe, you want to avoid the uncomfortable conversations, but I actually think the more direct you can be but also saying this is my intention. My intention is to set you up for success.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: A practical reframe: directness lands as care when you explicitly state your intent to help the person succeed.

quotes.topic_title: Direct feedback as an act of care
quotes.text: I think the only reason you would give that feedback is because they can do things differently and you just want to help support them.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: A mental model for when to give feedback: only do it when you believe change is possible and you’re committed to supporting it.

quotes.topic_title: Direct feedback as an act of care
quotes.text: I think in that conversation what's important is also saying, "I believe you can do all these things and I'm doing this to support you." Or, "I'm sharing this feedback because I believe in you."
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: Concrete language leaders can use to pair candid feedback with belief, reducing defensiveness and increasing motivation.

quotes.topic_title: Direct feedback as an act of care
quotes.text: And I think the third thing is as you give someone feedback, it should never sound like finger pointing or criticizing. It's really just, "Hey, this is what I observed, this is the impact that it had and here is a different way."
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: A simple, repeatable feedback structure (observation → impact → alternative) that keeps it about the work, not the person.

quotes.topic_title: Why develop internal talent versus hiring externally
quotes.text: Secondly, I think it's just makes a lot of sense as you're scaling a company that as you are growing, it just is a smoother transition that the folks on your team can grow with you.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: Highlights the practical scaling advantage of growing internal talent to reduce friction during growth.

quotes.topic_title: Why develop internal talent versus hiring externally
quotes.text: I actually think that extends to early employees too, that have built a ton of context on the user on how to get things done at the company.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: A contrarian extension of “founder intuition” to early employees as a form of institutional knowledge worth investing in.

quotes.topic_title: Why develop internal talent versus hiring externally
quotes.text: So the more that you develop talent within the company, the smoother transition is versus bringing someone from the outside where there's just a lot of different factors and there's risk there.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: Frames internal development as a risk-reduction strategy compared to external hiring.

quotes.topic_title: Why develop internal talent versus hiring externally
quotes.text: And so it really comes from a personal place, but also it makes a lot of sense from just like de-risking the situation as you're scaling.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: Connects the personal motivation to a clear business rationale leaders can apply: de-risk scaling by developing people.

quotes.topic_title: How to find mentors and growth-oriented managers
quotes.text: And even in the interview process, kind of interviewing your manager too and understanding what is their management philosophy, how do they think about your career path in that role? Those are things I would look for.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: A practical framework for evaluating a manager’s ability to develop you during the interview process.

quotes.topic_title: How to find mentors and growth-oriented managers
quotes.text: The second thing too is as you're interviewing, looking for a manager who especially your success will be tied to their success, this is actually what happened.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: A counterintuitive heuristic: pick roles where your manager is structurally incentivized to invest in your growth.

quotes.topic_title: How to find mentors and growth-oriented managers
quotes.text: I think Cheryl Sandberg had wrote this in her book Lean She basically writes about how some people will go, "Will you be my mentor?" And I've got that question too, and it's just a lot of pressure to get asked that question really early in and you don't really know the person.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: Explains why the direct “be my mentor” ask often backfires and why mentorship works better when it develops organically.

quotes.topic_title: How to find mentors and growth-oriented managers
quotes.text: And so I think it's also less about being frequently in touch and it's just going and reaching out when you actually have a problem.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: A simple operating model for mentorship: make it problem-driven rather than cadence-driven.

quotes.topic_title: Common ingredients of high-performing teams
quotes.text: I think it first starts with the team having a really clear goals. They need to know what success looks like.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: Emphasizes that high performance starts with explicit, shared definitions of success.

quotes.topic_title: Common ingredients of high-performing teams
quotes.text: So an example at Webflow is we have our growth team gold on ultimately the North Star is ARR, Annual Recurring Revenue. And then you break it down into the levers that drive ARR, the leading indicator, so that could be activation rates, the number of customers you bring in, et cetera.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: Provides a concrete goal-setting methodology: pick a North Star metric, then decompose it into controllable leading indicators.

quotes.topic_title: Common ingredients of high-performing teams
quotes.text: So something that someone on my team was saying the other day is you always make it really clear that we're going to be measured on impact and that's like how we are ultimately measured as a team.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: Shows how to operationalize a results-oriented culture by explicitly measuring the team on impact.

quotes.topic_title: Common ingredients of high-performing teams
quotes.text: I think that's what ends up being like a situation where one plus one equals three. You're not locally optimizing but you're thinking broader about the team and thinking beyond yourself.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: Captures the collaboration mental model: avoid local optimization to create compounding team outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Common ingredients of high-performing teams
quotes.text: As you scale, it's really easy to suddenly feel like that ownership is diluted.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: Highlights a scaling pitfall leaders can proactively design against: ownership naturally erodes as orgs grow.

quotes.topic_title: Creating ownership and team-first culture in practice
quotes.text: I think it first starts with defining the scope that everyone is going to own and drive.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: Ownership starts with intentionally designing independent, motivating scopes for each person rather than assuming it will emerge organically.

quotes.topic_title: Creating ownership and team-first culture in practice
quotes.text: And so I actually pushed back significantly though. I thought to myself, "If we double the team, what is everyone on the team going to own and drive?"
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: A counterintuitive scaling heuristic: don’t add headcount unless you can preserve meaningful ownership and scope per person.

quotes.topic_title: Creating ownership and team-first culture in practice
quotes.text: Let's say we want to run an experiment on this part of the product, maybe it's a core PM that kind of owns that service area that doesn't want to drive that thing or let's say or blocked by a bottleneck on designer engineering. It's something where I think if you're thinking an owner, you are not feeling easily disempowered because you can't do something and instead you're thinking, "What is everything I can do and did I exhaust all the options?"
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: A practical “owner mindset” reframes cross-functional blockers into a checklist of options to exhaust rather than a reason to stall.

quotes.topic_title: Creating ownership and team-first culture in practice
quotes.text: A good example here is I was actually driving pricing and packaging at Webflow for a very long time just because no one at the company was driving it and it was a huge opportunity area and I actually was doing it for enterprise pricing too.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: Concrete example of team-first leadership: stepping into unowned, high-leverage work outside formal scope to move the company forward.

quotes.topic_title: Creating ownership and team-first culture in practice
quotes.text: Also I find that putting a specific timeline like, "Hey, I'm going to do this thing for a quarter, but after that we really need to find somebody else to do it." Or hand it off is really helpful.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: A simple burnout-prevention mechanism: timebox “extra” responsibilities and plan a handoff upfront.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Wherever you work, running experiments is increasingly essential, but there are no commercial tools that integrate with a modern grow team stack.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical gap teams face when trying to operationalize experimentation within modern growth tooling.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: This leads to waste of time building internal tools or trying to run your own experiments through a clunky marketing tool.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Calls out the common hidden cost of experimentation: time lost to DIY infrastructure or misfit tools.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: When I was at Airbnb, one of the things that I loved most about working there was our experimentation platform where I was able to slice and dice data by device types, country, user stage, Eppo does all that and more delivering results quickly, avoiding annoying prolonged analytic cycles and helping you easily get to the root cause of any issue you discover.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides a concrete example of how segmentation plus faster analysis cycles improves experiment diagnosis and decision-making.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo lets you go beyond basic click-through metrics and instead use your North Star metrics like activation, retention, subscription and payments.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable measurement guidance: optimize experiments against North Star outcomes rather than shallow engagement metrics.

quotes.topic_title: How Melissa develops talent end-to-end
quotes.text: In terms of developing talent, I think of this as stages of the life cycle of your relationship, right?
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: Introduces a lifecycle framework for talent development that spans from hiring through long-term relationship building.

quotes.topic_title: How Melissa develops talent end-to-end
quotes.text: So how do I ramp them up as quickly as possible, connect them to the right people, the company? How do I also make sure it's clear what success looks like in their first 90 days? And then how do I help them secure early wins essentially?
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: A concrete onboarding playbook: fast ramp, key connections, explicit 90-day success criteria, and engineered early wins.

quotes.topic_title: How Melissa develops talent end-to-end
quotes.text: Here are some things where there's low hanging fruit or even rotting fruit that you should take on into secure early wins.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: Memorable tactic for finding quick-impact work—especially neglected problems—to build momentum and credibility early.

quotes.topic_title: How Melissa develops talent end-to-end
quotes.text: One recent hack I have is having folks on the team create looms that they can share with different leaders at Webflow.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: Specific, replicable mechanism for increasing visibility and stakeholder alignment without relying on hard-to-schedule meetings.

quotes.topic_title: How Melissa develops talent end-to-end
quotes.text: Yeah, care deeply but challenge directly and that has always been something that is something I try to infuse and has really inspired me as leader.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: A succinct leadership principle (Radical Candor) that operationalizes high-care, high-standards feedback.

quotes.topic_title: What she looks for in PMs and interview signals
quotes.text: The things that I lean especially heavy on in my interview process is this concept of first principles thinking or strong critical thinking.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: Highlights a specific, high-signal hiring criterion (first-principles/critical thinking) that can guide interview design and evaluation.

quotes.topic_title: What she looks for in PMs and interview signals
quotes.text: So usually there's some live problem solving component to my interview process where I really lean more heavily into how would you approach X problem? And then I dig into the Y and try to understand why would they approach it this way, see what questions they're asking and just see how they approach problem solving.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: Provides an actionable interview method: live problem-solving plus probing “why” and question quality to assess thinking, not just answers.

quotes.topic_title: What she looks for in PMs and interview signals
quotes.text: So really seeing how does this person take feedback.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: Defines a concrete way to evaluate growth mindset by focusing on feedback receptivity rather than self-reported traits.

quotes.topic_title: What she looks for in PMs and interview signals
quotes.text: And I recommend a prep call between the two of us before that presentation. And I actually will give feedback on the presentation.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: Shares a specific, replicable tactic—adding a prep call with feedback—to create a real-world collaboration signal during interviews.

quotes.topic_title: What she looks for in PMs and interview signals
quotes.text: And what this gives me signal is what is it actually going to be like to work together? And then I see how they incorporate it into the final product and that is always really interesting and sometimes it's the biggest signal to what it's going to be like to work with this person.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: Offers a counterintuitive evaluation lens: judge candidates by how they integrate feedback mid-process, which can outweigh other interview signals.

quotes.topic_title: Interview process setup (partial, transcript cut off)
quotes.text: Usually hiring manager screen, and I actually do the live problem solving at this screen. I actually think it weeds out the most people.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: She recommends moving live problem-solving into the hiring manager screen because it quickly differentiates candidates.

quotes.topic_title: Interview process setup (partial, transcript cut off)
quotes.text: One is a live problem solving. How would you approach X?
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: She describes a repeatable interview method: ask candidates to walk through their approach to a real problem.

quotes.topic_title: Interview process setup (partial, transcript cut off)
quotes.text: So let's say I'm hiring for pricing at Webflow, I would ask, "How would you approach pricing?"
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: She gives a concrete example of tailoring the live problem-solving prompt to the role’s core responsibility.

quotes.topic_title: Interview process setup (partial, transcript cut off)
quotes.text: I sometimes would say, "Hey, do you have your laptop? Can you pull up our pricing page? Curious to get your thoughts, what would you want to change?"
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: She shares a practical tactic: use the company’s real artifact (e.g., pricing page) to elicit specific, high-signal thinking.

quotes.topic_title: Interview process setup (partial, transcript cut off)
quotes.text: That was a trick I learned at Dropbox where we would actually pull up the Dropbox website and be like, "Hey, what'd you want to test here? Why?" And you get a ton of signal on how they approach the problem, how they think.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Tan
quotes.context: She explains why using a live product/website critique yields strong signal on candidate reasoning and experimentation instincts.
